nodes.bodyText:
In an ideal world the order of your plugins would not matter.  Even the metrics plugins would work if they did not have service ranking.  You just would not be sure how many plugins were party of that calculated latency.
In this PR you can see how the filterInjector bean loads in three filters before the delegate servlet filter.  Service ranking used by the delegate servlet filter cannot allow you to get in front of those 3 plugins.
I think this is a general problem with loosely coupled plugin systems.
CXF allows you to add an interceptor before or after another specific interceptor.  But that would not work in this case where I want to try to go first and last but still need to allow others to cut in front of me if necessary.
http://cxf.apache.org/docs/interceptors.html
Microprofile Config does something similar with their API using ordinal for each ConfigSource.
https://github.com/eclipse/microprofile-config#design
Java SPI will use instantiation order unless you provide a META-INF/services file to override that ordering.
https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/ServiceLoader.html
The SPI solution would work for how we deploy the system.  The trade off is you create a distribution configuration file that is aware of all plugins and is coupled to that implementation detail.

nodes.bodyText: ❓ I hate suggesting to expose more configuration, but given these values live upstream and are behind several iteration impediments, is there any value to exposing these through metatype? Or are these numbers fairly stable for all cases?

I think those numbers should be stable.  I based them off the defaults shown in the Micrometer examples.
https://micrometer.io/docs/concepts#_histograms_and_percentiles

If it’s so critical that we look at a lot of nines (and it is), why do most monitoring systems stop at the 95th or 99th percentile? The answer is simply because “it’s hard!” The data collected by most monitoring systems is usually summarized in small, five or ten second windows. This, combined with the fact that we can’t average percentiles or derive five nines from a bunch of small samples of percentiles means there’s no way to know what the 99.999th percentile for the minute or hour was. We end up throwing away a lot of good data and losing fidelity.
https://bravenewgeek.com/everything-you-know-about-latency-is-wrong/

I think Micrometer does use HdrHistogram though.

❓ Does this mean the metrics are taking into account "dead time" where processing has finished but now we're just waiting for the client to retrieve the result? Do we want that? Would misbehaved clients throw off our metrics? Or is that exactly the kind of info we're looking for?

I don't think so.  This is to support non-blocking IO servlets. I based this on how Dropwizard Metrics handles servlet metrics.
https://blogs.oracle.com/arungupta/non-blocking-io-using-servlet-31:-scalable-applications-using-java-ee-7-totd-188
Yeah if the servlets are still blocking the consumer but on the backend the thread ratio is no longer 1-to-1 for blocked consumer, then I think we're fine.
❓ Same question here about configuration.

❓ Is this giving us similar observability to dropwizard where we can actually detect if certain thread pools are under / over utilized or thrashing needlessly based on utilization?
Also average time spent waiting or blocked?
